ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Timepoint/visit label
Notes: e.g., Baseline, 6-Month Follow Up, Year 2; Morning, At Bedtime

ElementDescription: Since the divorce, my ex-spouse and I have tried to turn the children against the other parent.
Since the divorce, my ex-spouse and/or I have physically tried to hurt the other.
Since the divorce, I am much more strict with the children (spank, ground, or otherwise discipline) than I was before the divorce.
Since the divorce, I overuse drugs (i.e., alcohol, etc.).
Since the divorce, my ex-spouse and I have fought or criticized each other when the children were around.
Since the divorce, my children have had problems at school (lower grades, behavior problems, or refusal to go to school).
I think that sometimes my children feel as if it were somehow their fault that we got a divorce.
Since the divorce, my ex-spouse and I have yelled loudly at each other.
Since the divorce, my ex-spouse and I have argued about disciplining the children.
Before the divorce, people frequently hit each other in my family.
I think that my children feel differently toward me now than they did before the divorce.
Since the divorce, my children have acted aggressively (e.g., toward parents, siblings, or peers).
Before the divorce, family members avoided each other at home.
Since the divorce, I often feel less depressed (sleepless nights, crying, difficulty getting up in the morning).
Before the divorce, people frequently yelled at each other in my family.
My ability to provide for the children financially has been grossly affected.
The support payments I receive are inadequate.
Before the divorce, my ex-spouse and I often fought with each other while the children were around.
I cannot help blaming my ex-spouse for causing the break-up.
The support payments are a hardship for my ex-spouse.
Before the divorce, our financial situation often led to stress and arguments.
Our financial status since the divorce has made it necessary for us to move.
I think it would be best for all if we never see each other again.
Since the divorce, my ex-spouse has met his/her responsibilities in raising and providing support for the children.
I approve of the activities and care my children receive when they are with my ex-spouse.
My children are satisfied with the custody arrangement (e.g., they can see and talk with the other parent as much as they wish).
Since the divorce, my ex-spouse and I have agreed about most household decisions.
Although we had our problems, I am able to look back upon our years together as basically fond ones.
All things considered, the support payments are fair.
Before the divorce, our family discussed feelings and problems with each other.
Before the divorce, our family often did things together (e.g., ate dinner together).
Since the divorce, my children have had the opportunity to talk with other children (i.e., cousins or other family members, children at school, day care, the neighborhood, or at church).
Since the divorce, my children have had the opportunity to talk to other adults (i.e., family members, teachers/day care personnel, or their friends' parents).
Since the divorce, my children have been able to take part in one or more of the following: clubs, church, after-school or other activities

Since the divorce, I have been unable to take part in one or more of the following: hobbies, recreational activities, socializing with my friends, political organizations, and/or religious activities.
Since the divorce, my children have been able to take part in group or individual counseling.
I feel as if the children understand why my ex-spouse and I got a divorce.
Since the divorce, I have been able to take part in therapy or individual counseling.
Overall, my children have been able to cope with the divorce.
I think that the children understand that our divorce does NOT mean that either of us loves them any less.
Generally, I wish my children were more able to see more of their other parent than they do.
Overall, I think the divorce caused a lot of emotional problems for my child.
Divorce Adjustment Inventory - Revised (DAI-R) - Total Score
Notes: Sum of items dai_r1 through dai_r42

ElementDescription: Divorce Adjustment Inventory - Revised (DAI-R) - Family Conflict and Dysfunction Score
Notes: Sum of items dai_r1 through dai_r14

ElementDescription: Divorce Adjustment Inventory - Revised (DAI-R) - Favorable Divorce Conditions and Child Coping Ability Score
Notes: Sum of items dai_r15 through dai_r23

ElementDescription: Divorce Adjustment Inventory - Revised (DAI-R) - Positive Divorce Resolution Score
Notes: Sum of items dai_r24 through dai_r31

ElementDescription: Divorce Adjustment Inventory - Revised (DAI-R) - External Support Systems Score
Notes: Sum of items dai_r32 through dai_r34

ElementDescription: Divorce Adjustment Inventory - Revised (DAI-R) - Divorce Transition Score
Notes: Sum of items dai_r35 through dai_r42
